summary: Review of Recent Fitness Studies III: Volume, Frequency, Interval Training & More via /r/Fitness
title: Review of Recent Fitness Studies III: Volume, Frequency, Interval Training & More via /r/Fitness
body:
Hey guys, I’m back with more studies. Same drill as last time really. All for education and I hope we can spark some nice discussion like last time!

The first study we will take a look at is a new network meta-analysis conducted by Naci et al. (2018) which put exercise against blood pressure medications to see which one is more effective for reducing blood pressure. A network meta analysis is essentially a study that pools results from several studies together in one big analysis. The difference between a standard meta analysis and a network meta analysis can be elucidated with the following example. We want to see if a new magic pill is better than protein for lean mass gains. A standard meta analysis will only take results from papers where the pill and protein are directly compared with each other within one study. However, a network meta analysis will include studies where the pill is experimented is not compared with protein and is instead compared with something else like a placebo. We compare these kinds of studies together and we can make something called “indirect comparisons”. This type of analysis is very hard to carry out because you have to be very careful with your study selection and the vigilance for bias needs to be even greater than standard meta-analyses so kudos to the authors for putting together such a piece (Li et al. 2011).

The reason this study was done in such a manner was because there are actually no studies which directly compare blood pressure medications and exercise. The importance of this investigation is highlighted by the fact that high blood pressure is strongly linked with higher rates of cardiovascular diseases and medications naturally contribute to already expensive healthcare costs (Lewington, Clarke, Qizilbash, Peto and Collins, 2002; OECD, 2017). The increasing use of these medications also leads to problems like polypharmacy (use of many different medications for one individual) leads to issues like higher rates of adverse effects from medications.

This analysis decided to look a various types/intensities of exercises along with different types/doses of blood pressure lowering medication. The exercise modalities included endurance, dynamic, isometric and a combination of endurance and dynamic training. There was also analysis done at numerous baselines of blood pressure. An issue with the literature is that there are far more studies done with blood pressure medication than exercise regarding their potency to lower blood pressure. This is supported by the statistic that only 10% of the studies analyzed amongst the hypertensive (high blood pressure) population were from exercise studies. Exercise studies also generally had higher risks of bias and lower sample sizes.

When they pooled all the results together without sub-group analysis (i.e. no analysis on smaller, more specific groups of subjects), the medications outperformed exercise by about 4 units of blood pressure on average. Amongst the exercise types, every type performed about the same but the dynamic exercise (standard resistance training) did notably worse by a few units. You could see a positive correlation with drug dosage and blood pressure lowering effects but any correlation with exercise intensity was a lot more ambiguous.

However, we see a different story when we narrow the analysis to only hypertensive populations. As we increase the baseline blood pressure, exercise seems to show better results. In fact, as a whole, exercise performed on par with medications. Some exercise types (endurance and combination training especially) were actually found to be more effective than some medications. Intensities and doses did not show any differences.

Along with the issues previously described, there was no sorting of exercise studies based on their effectiveness. There are organizations which lay out guidelines for proper medication treatment which helps the authors weed out studies that may not be done properly in regards to medication administration but unfortunately, the same cannot be done for exercise studies. This is because there is no governing body which determines which exact programmes are effective or not. Therefore, it is possible that low-quality exercise studies were included in the analysis.

Most studies also start a healthy baseline while we would prefer to see studies done where baseline blood pressures were higher as this is the population we are concerned with. Finally, there needs more reporting of adverse effects in studies where exercise is the intervention. This is done meticulously in most clinical studies. In combination training, there may be a high adverse effect rate because aerobic training can be very fatiguing and negatively affect resistance training performance and safety.

As per the usual conclusions, more studies need to be done but these findings are very promising for exercise in a blood pressure control context. Perhaps in the future, it will be a far more common prescription in health care and maybe even find its way into first-line treatment in non-urgent cases.

TL;DR: In healthy people, medications outperform exercise in lower blood pressure. However, as we increase the baseline blood pressure amongst analyzed populations, exercise seems to perform just as good as medications. Endurance and combination training appear to have the greatest effects.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Now let’s look at a meta analysis looking at the relationship between muscular strength and mortality done by García-Hermoso et al. (2018). The analysis was done amongst healthy adults and 33 studies were included. Overall, it appeared that a greater muscular strength (looking at handgrip strength and leg extension strength) led to a reduced mortality rate. The reported numbers were a 31% reduction mortality with higher handgrip strength and a 14% reduction with higher leg extension strength. There were no differences amongst age groups but the positive effects of strength were more pronounced in women.

The authors noted a high heterogeneity in studies analyzed. This means that the studies differed widely in methods used. For example, some measured strength with handgrip strength (the most common measure) while some used other tools. This heterogeneity interferes with the pooling of the studies. Despite this, it does seem that the handgrip measure of strength could be of clinical use to assess mortality risk as it is the most popular tool in this literature.

TL;DR: Being stronger may help you live longer! However, more standardization in this area of research would help accrue better evidence.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

It is now time to journey into the world of frequency in training for a bit. It is a trending topic of research and as such, a few new studies have come out of the woods. I will follow a format of covering some recent interventional studies first and then reporting any new reviews/meta-analyses if available. For this article, we will look over the effects of frequency on strength and hypertrophy as those are common outcomes people will focus on.

The theories behind higher frequencies being better for strength include that higher frequencies allow for higher volumes, intensities can be more easily maintained when sessions are spread apart and more sessions give more opportunities to train the neural/motor aspect of strength training.

Ochi et al. (2018) put 20 untrained males through 11 weeks of training followed by 6 weeks of detraining. One group did 1 session a week consisting of 6 sets of 12 reps while the the other group did 3 sessions a week of 2 sets of 12 reps (only exercise performed throughout the study was the leg extension). The intensity was roughly maintained at 67% 1RM with volume matched between groups. Outcomes were one repetition maxima, thigh circumference, quadriceps muscle thickness, muscle stiffness (indicator of muscle damage) and maximum voluntary contraction torque (essentially how much force you can produce about a certain joint).

The higher frequency did have better 1 repetition maximum gains but the authors reported that there were no statistically significant differences and the standard deviations were quite wide. Regardless, this difference can be noted. Rate of perceived exertion was expectedly greater in the lower frequency group by about 30% on average throughout the study. Stiffness was similar between both groups. Thigh circumference had similar results to the 1 repetition maximum outcome in the sense that the higher frequency group had larger circumferences but no significant results were noted by the authors. While non-significance does support the evidence of there being no difference, statistical significance can be wildly variable and issues with this study’s design as well as no reporting of exact p-values, effect sizes and confidence intervals (for this outcome) do not help make a more solid conclusion. Muscle thickness through the measure of ultrasound was similar between groups.

The only statistically significant results reported by the researchers were that at 11 weeks, the maximum voluntary contraction torque was greater in the higher frequency group.

A few problems with this study include the low intensity used in this study. In the real life world, most strength-oriented programmes will use a very high intensity as intensity is an important factor in making strength improvements (Schoenfeld, Grgic, Ogborn & Krieger, 2017). There was no dietary control whatsoever. Finally, there was no control group. However, it was good of the authors to collect data at several time points as it is very common to only see data points at the beginning and end of a study.

TL;DR: Potentially more benefits in higher frequency training (thrice vs once a week), however, there are notable issues with the study design that can affect the conclusions we are able to garner from this study.

A meta-analysis conducted by Grgic et al. (2018) pooled 22 papers together to carefully examine the relationship between weekly training frequency and strength gains. 22 studies were included. Initially, we see a positive correlation between frequency and strength improvement. However, when we control for volume, as expected, we see no such correlation. While this is a common argument seen amongst those who support lower frequencies, I believe these findings are misapplied. Frequency should be seen as a good way to increase volume. Of course, independently, the current evidence points towards a weak correlation between frequency and strength but training with high volumes is much more manageable if the sessions are spread apart. The same findings can be found in a more recent meta-analysis conducted on the subject by Ralston et al. (2018).

Some patterns to note amongst the non-volume matched analyses is that young adults and women responded better to higher frequencies. Upper body, multi-joint exercises were also better with higher frequencies. Women may respond better due to generally having more type I fiber muscle composition which may make them more fatigue-resistant hence being able to handle more sessions per week than men (Haizlip, Harrison & Leinwand, 2015). Improvements in multi-joint exercises may be better because they require more complex motor recruitment patterns which may be poor at baseline but make significant improvements with frequent training. Upper body responds better possibly because the lower body is exposed to constant resistance during activities of daily living moreso than the upper body. Finally, young adults probably have better recovery than older adults which allow them to manage more training sessions per week (Roth et al., 2000).

A big gap in the literature is that there is a paucity of data in trained individuals. This meta-analysis could not even conduct a sub-group analysis amongst trained vs un-trained because there were not enough studies on trained people. More research definitely needs to be done in this population.

TL;DR: When equated for volume, higher frequencies will not do much for strength gains. However, they are a good way to boost training volume. Young adults, women, the upper body and multi-joint exercises may respond better to higher frequency training. More data on trained people is needed.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

We will now look at the effects of frequency on muscle hypertrophy. The theories for the relationship largely follow the same ones discussed in the strength literature above. However, muscle protein synthesis (muscle building at a molecular level) is a relevant part of the discussion here. Some theorize that because the muscle protein synthesis response post-exercise is limited to a period of time, it may be a good idea to do frequent sessions throughout the week to keep muscle protein synthesis elevated. This may have an even more pronounced effect in trained individuals because their muscle protein synthesis are generally blunted compared to the untrained population (Damas, Phillips, Vechin & Ugrinowitsch, 2015).

A trial ran by Saric et al. (2018) involved 27 trained men to be split into a 2 training groups: a group training 3 times a week and another training 6 times a week. The inclusion criteria for training history was that every subject must have trained at a frequency of at least twice a week for 6 months while training both the upper and lower body. Every set was taken to failure to keep rate of perceived exertion the same and volume was equated through the 6 weeks of exercise intervention. Even though the focus here is hypertrophy, the study outcomes include tests on strength and endurance. For strength, a 1 one repetition maximum bench press and squat test was done. For hypertrophy, ultrasounds were done at the biceps, triceps and 2 quadricep muscles. For endurance, a test where subjects performed the bench press and squat with a load of 60% of 1 repetition maximum for as many repetitions as possible.

Volume was generally greater for the higher frequency group. All of the volume differences were statistically insignificant except for the posterior thigh, however, nothing can really be extrapolated from this as the posterior thigh has little to no effect on any of the study outcomes. It’s hard to take any valuable information from this not purely because of the p values but also the deviations from the average were quite wide and comparing total volumes between groups when it is measured in setsrepetitionsload is difficult. This is because volume differences between specific exercises are much more valuable for analysis when measured in that method. Volume differences may be small between single-joint exercises like the bicep curl and then they can be bigger with higher load exercises like the squat. So if there are any discrepancies in volume, you cannot pinpoint which exercise it is in and therefore cannot extrapolate it to any specific body part.

Hypertrophy was very similar between groups but the lower frequency group was the only group to make gains the biceps. Both groups made gains in strength but no difference in improvements. Both groups did not make any real improvements in endurance.

We can see that frequency (3/week vs 6/week) does not really have that much of an effect on any outcome including muscle hypertrophy. Regarding the bicep finding, it is possibly because the bicep is included in more multi-joint exercises than the tricep so it perhaps underwent too much volume and suffered from recovery issues in the higher frequency group. A caveat with this study is that it is very short. Muscle hypertrophy is a slow process so studies should take more time to evaluate variables that may have an effect on it. Furthermore, there was no dietary control.

TL;DR: Training 6 times a week has no added benefit over training 3 times a week in not only muscle hypertrophy but muscular strength and endurance in the bench press and squat as well. Study would have been better with a longer duration and dietary control.

Just a few days ago, a meta-analysis by Schoenfeld, Grgic & Krieger (2018) exploring the relationship between muscle hypertrophy and training frequency was published. 25 studies were included with the minimum study duration being 6 weeks. There was a lot of different analyses done here. Relationships were checked under volume-equated conditions, under conditions where hypertrophy was measured directly and indirectly, for upper body and lower body and amongst trained individuals. Unfortunately, the meta-analysis could not include analysis on untrained individuals due to not having enough data.

Despite all the unique analyses, most of the effects training frequency could possibly muster were trivial. There were tiny effects even in conditions where volume was not equated. The only beacon of light was that under volume-equated conditions, the 3 times/week training frequency had a small (almost-moderate) effect size with the confidence intervals not including values supporting the hypothesis that frequency has no effect on muscle hypertrophy. The lower bound does not even fall into what we would consider trivial effect size. However, it must be noted that the result was statistically insignificant.

With the prolonged muscle protein synthesis theory in mind, these results promote caution in those who associate chronic muscular hypertrophy to acute muscle protein synthesis responses. Limitations include that these results only apply to the upper limbs, it is still up in the air whether or not single or multi-joint exercises play a part and that there is no control for other variables like diet, rest or training to failure (however, the meta-analysis reports very low heterogeneity all around and all the studies included should have done their own controlling for these variables).

TL;DR: Even if you do not control volume, it seems frequency has a very minor role to play in hypertrophy yet there are more areas of research to explore, for example, the effects of training frequency on the calf muscles.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Schoenfeld et al. (2018) decided to see what kind of muscular responses we would get at higher volumes compared to lower volumes. 34, well-trained men (mean training history was 4.5 years) were split into 3 groups where they either did 1 set, 3 sets or 5 sets per exercise every session. Training sessions were held 3 times a week and the programme lasted 8 weeks. All sets were taken to failure to match for rate of perceived exertion. An ultrasound machine was used to assess muscle thickness. Squat and bench press tests were used to determine strength improvements. Endurance was tested with a set of bench press at 50% of 1 repetition maximum done at as many repetitions as possible. For dietary control, a dietary log was completed on 5 different days in week 0 and week 8. A 24 gram protein supplement was also given on training days.

The 1 set group had the shortest training sessions at 13 minutes on average whereas the 5 set group obviously had the longest sessions at 68 minutes on average. The average time for the 3 set group was 40 minutes. Strength improvements were similar across groups. Endurance improvements were also similar between groups. Hypertrophy followed a positive correlation in most muscles with evidence towards there being a relationship being highest in the quadriceps. The only muscle that did not support evidence of such a relationship was the triceps. Although, the raw data did show some positive correlation if you follow the effect sizes. Diet composition did not differ by much between groups.

The hypertrophy results were likely expected. The similar strength improvements were likely because volume is not the main driving factor in strength gains and it is probably attributed more to something like loads. The same can be said for endurance (a different driver at play). One may argue that the even though the strength improvements are similar, the lower volume groups are at an efficiency advantage due to shorter training sessions. However, these results do not really translate well into the real-life world in this context. This is because strength training sets are generally done at very high intensities where less repetitions are done, rest times are longer and sets are shorter or potentially longer than the times seen in this study. Training history may have not been adequately controlled since training at 5 days a week could have been a novelty for some participants offering a potentially greater improvement in performance. Dietary control could have also been made a more regular requirement throughout the study rather than just having it at the beginning and the end.

TL;DR: Hypertrophy has a positive correlation with number of weekly working sets up to 5 sets per exercise. Strength and endurance are likely driven by other variables like load or frequency.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

To conclude this piece, we will cover a paper completed by Naves et al. (2018). The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of high intensity interval training and sprint interval training on body composition and heart health in 49 healthy, women. All interval training was done on a machine bicycle. High intensity interval training (HIIT) involved doing four 4-minute efforts at 90–95% of maximum heart rate with 3 minutes of active rest in between (active rest = 50–60% of maximum heart rate). The sprint interval training (SIT) involved four 30-second all-out efforts with 4 minutes of light cycling in between. Sessions were done 3 times a week for 8 weeks. Study outcomes include waist circumference, skinfolds (to check body fat) and VO2 peak (a measure of endurance or a measure of how healthy the heart is). Diet was controlled with three 24-hour diet recalls at the beginning and end of the study.

Adherence in both groups was only 75% in both groups which is quite poor. 3 subjects reported adverse effects (dizziness and vomiting). Only the SIT group had statistically significant reductions in body mass but effect sizes were similar in both groups. The reduction in the sum of all skinfolds was greatest in the SIT group with a 22.2% reduction compared to the HIIT group’s reduction of 15.8%.

Reductions in waist circumference were similar between groups. VO2 improvements were also similar. The average timing of the SIT group’s training sessions were 10 minutes shorter on average (23 vs 33 minutes).

It appears that SIT leads to greater fat mass reductions while having shorter training sessions compared to HIIT. Another benefit of SIT is that to perform it, you do not need to know your maximum heart rate. Limitations of the study include not having a more thorough dietary control and the use of skinfolds instead of gold standards like magnetic resonance imaging for measuring body fat.

TL;DR: Sprint interval training led to greater fat loss compared to high intensity interval training in women. Sprint interval training sessions were also shorter on average by 10 minutes. Adherence may be an issue and athletes should be aware of possible adverse effects when undergoing interval training.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

García-Hermoso, A., Cavero-Redondo, I., Ramírez-Vélez, R., Ruiz, J. R., Ortega, F. B., Lee, D. & Martínez-Vizcaíno, V. (2018). Muscular Strength as a Predictor of All-Cause Mortality in an Apparently Healthy Population: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis of Data From Approximately 2 Million Men and Women. Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, 99(10), 2100–2113.

Grgic, J., Schoenfeld, B., Davies, T. B., Lazinica, B., Krieger, J. W. & Pedisic, Z. (2018). Effect of Resistance Training Frequency on Gains in Muscular Strength: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Sports Medicine, 48(5), 1207–1220.

Li, T., Puhan, M. A., Vedula, S. S., Singh, S. & Dickersin, K. (2011). Network meta-analysis-highly attractive but more methodological research is needed. BioMed Central, 9(79), .

A network meta-analysis of 391 randomised controlled trials assessing exercise and medication effects on systolic blood pressure. British Journal of Sports Medicine, .

Naves, J. P. A., Viana, R. B., Rebelo, A. C. S., de Lira, C. A. B., Pimentel, G. D., Lobo, P. C. B., de Oliveira, J. C., … Gentil, P. (2018). TL;DR: In healthy people, medications outperform exercise in lower blood pressure. However, as we increase the baseline blood pressure amongst analyzed populations, exercise seems to perform just as good as medications. Endurance and combination training appear to have the greatest effects.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Now let’s look at a meta analysis looking at the relationship between muscular strength and mortality done by García-Hermoso et al. (2018). The analysis was done amongst healthy adults and 33 studies were included. Overall, it appeared that a greater muscular strength (looking at handgrip strength and leg extension strength) led to a reduced mortality rate. The reported numbers were a 31% reduction mortality with higher handgrip strength and a 14% reduction with higher leg extension strength. There were no differences amongst age groups but the positive effects of strength were more pronounced in women.

The authors noted a high heterogeneity in studies analyzed. This means that the studies differed widely in methods used. For example, some measured strength with handgrip strength (the most common measure) while some used other tools. This heterogeneity interferes with the pooling of the studies. Despite this, it does seem that the handgrip measure of strength could be of clinical use to assess mortality risk as it is the most popular tool in this literature.

TL;DR: Being stronger may help you live longer! However, more standardization in this area of research would help accrue better evidence.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

It is now time to journey into the world of frequency in training for a bit. It is a trending topic of research and as such, a few new studies have come out of the woods. I will follow a format of covering some recent interventional studies first and then reporting any new reviews/meta-analyses if available. For this article, we will look over the effects of frequency on strength and hypertrophy as those are common outcomes people will focus on.

The theories behind higher frequencies being better for strength include that higher frequencies allow for higher volumes, intensities can be more easily maintained when sessions are spread apart and more sessions give more opportunities to train the neural/motor aspect of strength training.

Ochi et al. (2018) put 20 untrained males through 11 weeks of training followed by 6 weeks of detraining. One group did 1 session a week consisting of 6 sets of 12 reps while the the other group did 3 sessions a week of 2 sets of 12 reps (only exercise performed throughout the study was the leg extension). The intensity was roughly maintained at 67% 1RM with volume matched between groups. Outcomes were one repetition maxima, thigh circumference, quadriceps muscle thickness, muscle stiffness (indicator of muscle damage) and maximum voluntary contraction torque (essentially how much force you can produce about a certain joint).

The higher frequency did have better 1 repetition maximum gains but the authors reported that there were no statistically significant differences and the standard deviations were quite wide. Regardless, this difference can be noted. Rate of perceived exertion was expectedly greater in the lower frequency group by about 30% on average throughout the study. Stiffness was similar between both groups. Thigh circumference had similar results to the 1 repetition maximum outcome in the sense that the higher frequency group had larger circumferences but no significant results were noted by the authors. While non-significance does support the evidence of there being no difference, statistical significance can be wildly variable and issues with this study’s design as well as no reporting of exact p-values, effect sizes and confidence intervals (for this outcome) do not help make a more solid conclusion. Muscle thickness through the measure of ultrasound was similar between groups.

The only statistically significant results reported by the researchers were that at 11 weeks, the maximum voluntary contraction torque was greater in the higher frequency group.

A few problems with this study include the low intensity used in this study. In the real life world, most strength-oriented programmes will use a very high intensity as intensity is an important factor in making strength improvements (Schoenfeld, Grgic, Ogborn & Krieger, 2017). There was no dietary control whatsoever. Finally, there was no control group. However, it was good of the authors to collect data at several time points as it is very common to only see data points at the beginning and end of a study.

TL;DR: Potentially more benefits in higher frequency training (thrice vs once a week), however, there are notable issues with the study design that can affect the conclusions we are able to garner from this study.

A meta-analysis conducted by Grgic et al. (2018) pooled 22 papers together to carefully examine the relationship between weekly training frequency and strength gains. 22 studies were included. Initially, we see a positive correlation between frequency and strength improvement. However, when we control for volume, as expected, we see no such correlation. While this is a common argument seen amongst those who support lower frequencies, I believe these findings are misapplied. Frequency should be seen as a good way to increase volume. Of course, independently, the current evidence points towards a weak correlation between frequency and strength but training with high volumes is much more manageable if the sessions are spread apart. The same findings can be found in a more recent meta-analysis conducted on the subject by Ralston et al. (2018).

Some patterns to note amongst the non-volume matched analyses is that young adults and women responded better to higher frequencies. Upper body, multi-joint exercises were also better with higher frequencies. Women may respond better due to generally having more type I fiber muscle composition which may make them more fatigue-resistant hence being able to handle more sessions per week than men (Haizlip, Harrison & Leinwand, 2015). Improvements in multi-joint exercises may be better because they require more complex motor recruitment patterns which may be poor at baseline but make significant improvements with frequent training. Upper body responds better possibly because the lower body is exposed to constant resistance during activities of daily living moreso than the upper body. Finally, young adults probably have better recovery than older adults which allow them to manage more training sessions per week (Roth et al., 2000).

A big gap in the literature is that there is a paucity of data in trained individuals. This meta-analysis could not even conduct a sub-group analysis amongst trained vs un-trained because there were not enough studies on trained people. More research definitely needs to be done in this population.

TL;DR: When equated for volume, higher frequencies will not do much for strength gains. However, they are a good way to boost training volume. Young adults, women, the upper body and multi-joint exercises may respond better to higher frequency training. More data on trained people is needed.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

We will now look at the effects of frequency on muscle hypertrophy. The theories for the relationship largely follow the same ones discussed in the strength literature above. However, muscle protein synthesis (muscle building at a molecular level) is a relevant part of the discussion here. Some theorize that because the muscle protein synthesis response post-exercise is limited to a period of time, it may be a good idea to do frequent sessions throughout the week to keep muscle protein synthesis elevated. This may have an even more pronounced effect in trained individuals because their muscle protein synthesis are generally blunted compared to the untrained population (Damas, Phillips, Vechin & Ugrinowitsch, 2015).

A trial ran by Saric et al. (2018) involved 27 trained men to be split into a 2 training groups: a group training 3 times a week and another training 6 times a week. The inclusion criteria for training history was that every subject must have trained at a frequency of at least twice a week for 6 months while training both the upper and lower body. Every set was taken to failure to keep rate of perceived exertion the same and volume was equated through the 6 weeks of exercise intervention. Even though the focus here is hypertrophy, the study outcomes include tests on strength and endurance. For strength, a 1 one repetition maximum bench press and squat test was done. For hypertrophy, ultrasounds were done at the biceps, triceps and 2 quadricep muscles. For endurance, a test where subjects performed the bench press and squat with a load of 60% of 1 repetition maximum for as many repetitions as possible.

Volume was generally greater for the higher frequency group. All of the volume differences were statistically insignificant except for the posterior thigh, however, nothing can really be extrapolated from this as the posterior thigh has little to no effect on any of the study outcomes. It’s hard to take any valuable information from this not purely because of the p values but also the deviations from the average were quite wide and comparing total volumes between groups when it is measured in setsrepetitionsload is difficult. This is because volume differences between specific exercises are much more valuable for analysis when measured in that method. Volume differences may be small between single-joint exercises like the bicep curl and then they can be bigger with higher load exercises like the squat. So if there are any discrepancies in volume, you cannot pinpoint which exercise it is in and therefore cannot extrapolate it to any specific body part.

Hypertrophy was very similar between groups but the lower frequency group was the only group to make gains the biceps. Both groups made gains in strength but no difference in improvements. Both groups did not make any real improvements in endurance.

We can see that frequency (3/week vs 6/week) does not really have that much of an effect on any outcome including muscle hypertrophy. Regarding the bicep finding, it is possibly because the bicep is included in more multi-joint exercises than the tricep so it perhaps underwent too much volume and suffered from recovery issues in the higher frequency group. A caveat with this study is that it is very short. Muscle hypertrophy is a slow process so studies should take more time to evaluate variables that may have an effect on it. Furthermore, there was no dietary control.

TL;DR: Training 6 times a week has no added benefit over training 3 times a week in not only muscle hypertrophy but muscular strength and endurance in the bench press and squat as well. Study would have been better with a longer duration and dietary control.

Just a few days ago, a meta-analysis by Schoenfeld, Grgic & Krieger (2018) exploring the relationship between muscle hypertrophy and training frequency was published. 25 studies were included with the minimum study duration being 6 weeks. There was a lot of different analyses done here. Relationships were checked under volume-equated conditions, under conditions where hypertrophy was measured directly and indirectly, for upper body and lower body and amongst trained individuals. Unfortunately, the meta-analysis could not include analysis on untrained individuals due to not having enough data.

Despite all the unique analyses, most of the effects training frequency could possibly muster were trivial. There were tiny effects even in conditions where volume was not equated. The only beacon of light was that under volume-equated conditions, the 3 times/week training frequency had a small (almost-moderate) effect size with the confidence intervals not including values supporting the hypothesis that frequency has no effect on muscle hypertrophy. The lower bound does not even fall into what we would consider trivial effect size. However, it must be noted that the result was statistically insignificant.

With the prolonged muscle protein synthesis theory in mind, these results promote caution in those who associate chronic muscular hypertrophy to acute muscle protein synthesis responses. Limitations include that these results only apply to the upper limbs, it is still up in the air whether or not single or multi-joint exercises play a part and that there is no control for other variables like diet, rest or training to failure (however, the meta-analysis reports very low heterogeneity all around and all the studies included should have done their own controlling for these variables).

TL;DR: Even if you do not control volume, it seems frequency has a very minor role to play in hypertrophy yet there are more areas of research to explore, for example, the effects of training frequency on the calf muscles.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Schoenfeld et al. (2018) decided to see what kind of muscular responses we would get at higher volumes compared to lower volumes. 34, well-trained men (mean training history was 4.5 years) were split into 3 groups where they either did 1 set, 3 sets or 5 sets per exercise every session. Training sessions were held 3 times a week and the programme lasted 8 weeks. All sets were taken to failure to match for rate of perceived exertion. An ultrasound machine was used to assess muscle thickness. Squat and bench press tests were used to determine strength improvements. Endurance was tested with a set of bench press at 50% of 1 repetition maximum done at as many repetitions as possible. For dietary control, a dietary log was completed on 5 different days in week 0 and week 8. A 24 gram protein supplement was also given on training days.

The 1 set group had the shortest training sessions at 13 minutes on average whereas the 5 set group obviously had the longest sessions at 68 minutes on average. The average time for the 3 set group was 40 minutes. Strength improvements were similar across groups. Endurance improvements were also similar between groups. Hypertrophy followed a positive correlation in most muscles with evidence towards there being a relationship being highest in the quadriceps. The only muscle that did not support evidence of such a relationship was the triceps. Although, the raw data did show some positive correlation if you follow the effect sizes. Diet composition did not differ by much between groups.

The hypertrophy results were likely expected. The similar strength improvements were likely because volume is not the main driving factor in strength gains and it is probably attributed more to something like loads. The same can be said for endurance (a different driver at play). One may argue that the even though the strength improvements are similar, the lower volume groups are at an efficiency advantage due to shorter training sessions. However, these results do not really translate well into the real-life world in this context. This is because strength training sets are generally done at very high intensities where less repetitions are done, rest times are longer and sets are shorter or potentially longer than the times seen in this study. Training history may have not been adequately controlled since training at 5 days a week could have been a novelty for some participants offering a potentially greater improvement in performance. Dietary control could have also been made a more regular requirement throughout the study rather than just having it at the beginning and the end.

TL;DR: Hypertrophy has a positive correlation with number of weekly working sets up to 5 sets per exercise. Strength and endurance are likely driven by other variables like load or frequency.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

To conclude this piece, we will cover a paper completed by Naves et al. (2018). The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of high intensity interval training and sprint interval training on body composition and heart health in 49 healthy, women. All interval training was done on a machine bicycle. High intensity interval training (HIIT) involved doing four 4-minute efforts at 90–95% of maximum heart rate with 3 minutes of active rest in between (active rest = 50–60% of maximum heart rate). The sprint interval training (SIT) involved four 30-second all-out efforts with 4 minutes of light cycling in between. Sessions were done 3 times a week for 8 weeks. Study outcomes include waist circumference, skinfolds (to check body fat) and VO2 peak (a measure of endurance or a measure of how healthy the heart is). Diet was controlled with three 24-hour diet recalls at the beginning and end of the study.

Adherence in both groups was only 75% in both groups which is quite poor. 3 subjects reported adverse effects (dizziness and vomiting). Only the SIT group had statistically significant reductions in body mass but effect sizes were similar in both groups. The reduction in the sum of all skinfolds was greatest in the SIT group with a 22.2% reduction compared to the HIIT group’s reduction of 15.8%.

Reductions in waist circumference were similar between groups. VO2 improvements were also similar. The average timing of the SIT group’s training sessions were 10 minutes shorter on average (23 vs 33 minutes).

It appears that SIT leads to greater fat mass reductions while having shorter training sessions compared to HIIT. Another benefit of SIT is that to perform it, you do not need to know your maximum heart rate. Limitations of the study include not having a more thorough dietary control and the use of skinfolds instead of gold standards like magnetic resonance imaging for measuring body fat.

TL;DR: Sprint interval training led to greater fat loss compared to high intensity interval training in women. Sprint interval training sessions were also shorter on average by 10 minutes. Adherence may be an issue and athletes should be aware of possible adverse effects when undergoing interval training.

trail.content_raw:
Hey guys, I’m back with more studies. Same drill as last time really. All for education and I hope we can spark some nice discussion like last time!

The first study we will take a look at is a new network meta-analysis conducted by Naci et al. (2018) which put exercise against blood pressure medications to see which one is more effective for reducing blood pressure. A network meta analysis is essentially a study that pools results from several studies together in one big analysis. The difference between a standard meta analysis and a network meta analysis can be elucidated with the following example. We want to see if a new magic pill is better than protein for lean mass gains. A standard meta analysis will only take results from papers where the pill and protein are directly compared with each other within one study. However, a network meta analysis will include studies where the pill is experimented is not compared with protein and is instead compared with something else like a placebo. We compare these kinds of studies together and we can make something called “indirect comparisons”. This type of analysis is very hard to carry out because you have to be very careful with your study selection and the vigilance for bias needs to be even greater than standard meta-analyses so kudos to the authors for putting together such a piece (Li et al. 2011).

The reason this study was done in such a manner was because there are actually no studies which directly compare blood pressure medications and exercise. The importance of this investigation is highlighted by the fact that high blood pressure is strongly linked with higher rates of cardiovascular diseases and medications naturally contribute to already expensive healthcare costs (Lewington, Clarke, Qizilbash, Peto and Collins, 2002; OECD, 2017). The increasing use of these medications also leads to problems like polypharmacy (use of many different medications for one individual) leads to issues like higher rates of adverse effects from medications.

This analysis decided to look a various types/intensities of exercises along with different types/doses of blood pressure lowering medication. The exercise modalities included endurance, dynamic, isometric and a combination of endurance and dynamic training. There was also analysis done at numerous baselines of blood pressure. An issue with the literature is that there are far more studies done with blood pressure medication than exercise regarding their potency to lower blood pressure. This is supported by the statistic that only 10% of the studies analyzed amongst the hypertensive (high blood pressure) population were from exercise studies. Exercise studies also generally had higher risks of bias and lower sample sizes.

When they pooled all the results together without sub-group analysis (i.e. no analysis on smaller, more specific groups of subjects), the medications outperformed exercise by about 4 units of blood pressure on average. Amongst the exercise types, every type performed about the same but the dynamic exercise (standard resistance training) did notably worse by a few units. You could see a positive correlation with drug dosage and blood pressure lowering effects but any correlation with exercise intensity was a lot more ambiguous.

However, we see a different story when we narrow the analysis to only hypertensive populations. As we increase the baseline blood pressure, exercise seems to show better results. In fact, as a whole, exercise performed on par with medications. Some exercise types (endurance and combination training especially) were actually found to be more effective than some medications. Intensities and doses did not show any differences.

Along with the issues previously described, there was no sorting of exercise studies based on their effectiveness. There are organizations which lay out guidelines for proper medication treatment which helps the authors weed out studies that may not be done properly in regards to medication administration but unfortunately, the same cannot be done for exercise studies. This is because there is no governing body which determines which exact programmes are effective or not. Therefore, it is possible that low-quality exercise studies were included in the analysis.

Most studies also start a healthy baseline while we would prefer to see studies done where baseline blood pressures were higher as this is the population we are concerned with. Finally, there needs more reporting of adverse effects in studies where exercise is the intervention. This is done meticulously in most clinical studies. In combination training, there may be a high adverse effect rate because aerobic training can be very fatiguing and negatively affect resistance training performance and safety.

As per the usual conclusions, more studies need to be done but these findings are very promising for exercise in a blood pressure control context. Perhaps in the future, it will be a far more common prescription in health care and maybe even find its way into first-line treatment in non-urgent cases.

TL;DR: In healthy people, medications outperform exercise in lower blood pressure. However, as we increase the baseline blood pressure amongst analyzed populations, exercise seems to perform just as good as medications. Endurance and combination training appear to have the greatest effects.

However, muscle protein synthesis (muscle building at a molecular level) is a relevant part of the discussion here. Some theorize that because the muscle protein synthesis response post-exercise is limited to a period of time, it may be a good idea to do frequent sessions throughout the week to keep muscle protein synthesis elevated. This may have an even more pronounced effect in trained individuals because their muscle protein synthesis are generally blunted compared to the untrained population (Damas, Phillips, Vechin & Ugrinowitsch, 2015).

A trial ran by Saric et al. (2018) involved 27 trained men to be split into a 2 training groups: a group training 3 times a week and another training 6 times a week. The inclusion criteria for training history was that every subject must have trained at a frequency of at least twice a week for 6 months while training both the upper and lower body. Every set was taken to failure to keep rate of perceived exertion the same and volume was equated through the 6 weeks of exercise intervention. Even though the focus here is hypertrophy, the study outcomes include tests on strength and endurance. For strength, a 1 one repetition maximum bench press and squat test was done. For hypertrophy, ultrasounds were done at the biceps, triceps and 2 quadricep muscles. For endurance, a test where subjects performed the bench press and squat with a load of 60% of 1 repetition maximum for as many repetitions as possible.

Volume was generally greater for the higher frequency group. All of the volume differences were statistically insignificant except for the posterior thigh, however, nothing can really be extrapolated from this as the posterior thigh has little to no effect on any of the study outcomes. It’s hard to take any valuable information from this not purely because of the p values but also the deviations from the average were quite wide and comparing total volumes between groups when it is measured in setsrepetitionsload is difficult. This is because volume differences between specific exercises are much more valuable for analysis when measured in that method. Volume differences may be small between single-joint exercises like the bicep curl and then they can be bigger with higher load exercises like the squat. So if there are any discrepancies in volume, you cannot pinpoint which exercise it is in and therefore cannot extrapolate it to any specific body part.

Hypertrophy was very similar between groups but the lower frequency group was the only group to make gains the biceps. Both groups made gains in strength but no difference in improvements. Both groups did not make any real improvements in endurance.

We can see that frequency (3/week vs 6/week) does not really have that much of an effect on any outcome including muscle hypertrophy. Regarding the bicep finding, it is possibly because the bicep is included in more multi-joint exercises than the tricep so it perhaps underwent too much volume and suffered from recovery issues in the higher frequency group. A caveat with this study is that it is very short. Muscle hypertrophy is a slow process so studies should take more time to evaluate variables that may have an effect on it. Furthermore, there was no dietary control.

TL;DR: Training 6 times a week has no added benefit over training 3 times a week in not only muscle hypertrophy but muscular strength and endurance in the bench press and squat as well. Study would have been better with a longer duration and dietary control.

Just a few days ago, a meta-analysis by Schoenfeld, Grgic & Krieger (2018) exploring the relationship between muscle hypertrophy and training frequency was published. 25 studies were included with the minimum study duration being 6 weeks. There was a lot of different analyses done here. Relationships were checked under volume-equated conditions, under conditions where hypertrophy was measured directly and indirectly, for upper body and lower body and amongst trained individuals. Unfortunately, the meta-analysis could not include analysis on untrained individuals due to not having enough data.

Despite all the unique analyses, most of the effects training frequency could possibly muster were trivial. There were tiny effects even in conditions where volume was not equated. The only beacon of light was that under volume-equated conditions, the 3 times/week training frequency had a small (almost-moderate) effect size with the confidence intervals not including values supporting the hypothesis that frequency has no effect on muscle hypertrophy. The lower bound does not even fall into what we would consider trivial effect size. However, it must be noted that the result was statistically insignificant.

With the prolonged muscle protein synthesis theory in mind, these results promote caution in those who associate chronic muscular hypertrophy to acute muscle protein synthesis responses. Limitations include that these results only apply to the upper limbs, it is still up in the air whether or not single or multi-joint exercises play a part and that there is no control for other variables like diet, rest or training to failure (however, the meta-analysis reports very low heterogeneity all around and all the studies included should have done their own controlling for these variables).

TL;DR: Even if you do not control volume, it seems frequency has a very minor role to play in hypertrophy yet there are more areas of research to explore, for example, the effects of training frequency on the calf muscles.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Schoenfeld et al. (2018) decided to see what kind of muscular responses we would get at higher volumes compared to lower volumes. 34, well-trained men (mean training history was 4.5 years) were split into 3 groups where they either did 1 set, 3 sets or 5 sets per exercise every session. Training sessions were held 3 times a week and the programme lasted 8 weeks. All sets were taken to failure to match for rate of perceived exertion. An ultrasound machine was used to assess muscle thickness. Squat and bench press tests were used to determine strength improvements. Endurance was tested with a set of bench press at 50% of 1 repetition maximum done at as many repetitions as possible. For dietary control, a dietary log was completed on 5 different days in week 0 and week 8. A 24 gram protein supplement was also given on training days.

The 1 set group had the shortest training sessions at 13 minutes on average whereas the 5 set group obviously had the longest sessions at 68 minutes on average. The average time for the 3 set group was 40 minutes. Strength improvements were similar across groups. Endurance improvements were also similar between groups. Hypertrophy followed a positive correlation in most muscles with evidence towards there being a relationship being highest in the quadriceps. The only muscle that did not support evidence of such a relationship was the triceps. Although, the raw data did show some positive correlation if you follow the effect sizes. Diet composition did not differ by much between groups.

The hypertrophy results were likely expected. The similar strength improvements were likely because volume is not the main driving factor in strength gains and it is probably attributed more to something like loads. The same can be said for endurance (a different driver at play). One may argue that the even though the strength improvements are similar, the lower volume groups are at an efficiency advantage due to shorter training sessions. However, these results do not really translate well into the real-life world in this context. This is because strength training sets are generally done at very high intensities where less repetitions are done, rest times are longer and sets are shorter or potentially longer than the times seen in this study. Training history may have not been adequately controlled since training at 5 days a week could have been a novelty for some participants offering a potentially greater improvement in performance. Dietary control could have also been made a more regular requirement throughout the study rather than just having it at the beginning and the end.

TL;DR: Hypertrophy has a positive correlation with number of weekly working sets up to 5 sets per exercise. Strength and endurance are likely driven by other variables like load or frequency.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

To conclude this piece, we will cover a paper completed by Naves et al. (2018). The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of high intensity interval training and sprint interval training on body composition and heart health in 49 healthy, women. All interval training was done on a machine bicycle. High intensity interval training (HIIT) involved doing four 4-minute efforts at 90–95% of maximum heart rate with 3 minutes of active rest in between (active rest = 50–60% of maximum heart rate). The sprint interval training (SIT) involved four 30-second all-out efforts with 4 minutes of light cycling in between. Sessions were done 3 times a week for 8 weeks. Study outcomes include waist circumference, skinfolds (to check body fat) and VO2 peak (a measure of endurance or a measure of how healthy the heart is). Diet was controlled with three 24-hour diet recalls at the beginning and end of the study.

Adherence in both groups was only 75% in both groups which is quite poor. 3 subjects reported adverse effects (dizziness and vomiting). Only the SIT group had statistically significant reductions in body mass but effect sizes were similar in both groups. The reduction in the sum of all skinfolds was greatest in the SIT group with a 22.2% reduction compared to the HIIT group’s reduction of 15.8%.

Reductions in waist circumference were similar between groups. VO2 improvements were also similar. The average timing of the SIT group’s training sessions were 10 minutes shorter on average (23 vs 33 minutes).

It appears that SIT leads to greater fat mass reductions while having shorter training sessions compared to HIIT. Another benefit of SIT is that to perform it, you do not need to know your maximum heart rate. Limitations of the study include not having a more thorough dietary control and the use of skinfolds instead of gold standards like magnetic resonance imaging for measuring body fat.

TL;DR: Sprint interval training led to greater fat loss compared to high intensity interval training in women. Sprint interval training sessions were also shorter on average by 10 minutes. Adherence may be an issue and athletes should be aware of possible adverse effects when undergoing interval training.

trail.content:
Hey guys, I’m back with more studies. Same drill as last time really. All for education and I hope we can spark some nice discussion like last time!

The first study we will take a look at is a new network meta-analysis conducted by Naci et al. (2018) which put exercise against blood pressure medications to see which one is more effective for reducing blood pressure. A network meta analysis is essentially a study that pools results from several studies together in one big analysis. The difference between a standard meta analysis and a network meta analysis can be elucidated with the following example. We want to see if a new magic pill is better than protein for lean mass gains. A standard meta analysis will only take results from papers where the pill and protein are directly compared with each other within one study. However, a network meta analysis will include studies where the pill is experimented is not compared with protein and is instead compared with something else like a placebo. We compare these kinds of studies together and we can make something called “indirect comparisons”. This type of analysis is very hard to carry out because you have to be very careful with your study selection and the vigilance for bias needs to be even greater than standard meta-analyses so kudos to the authors for putting together such a piece (Li et al. 2011).

The reason this study was done in such a manner was because there are actually no studies which directly compare blood pressure medications and exercise. The importance of this investigation is highlighted by the fact that high blood pressure is strongly linked with higher rates of cardiovascular diseases and medications naturally contribute to already expensive healthcare costs (Lewington, Clarke, Qizilbash, Peto and Collins, 2002; OECD, 2017). The increasing use of these medications also leads to problems like polypharmacy (use of many different medications for one individual) leads to issues like higher rates of adverse effects from medications.

This analysis decided to look a various types/intensities of exercises along with different types/doses of blood pressure lowering medication. The exercise modalities included endurance, dynamic, isometric and a combination of endurance and dynamic training. There was also analysis done at numerous baselines of blood pressure. An issue with the literature is that there are far more studies done with blood pressure medication than exercise regarding their potency to lower blood pressure. This is supported by the statistic that only 10% of the studies analyzed amongst the hypertensive (high blood pressure) population were from exercise studies. Exercise studies also generally had higher risks of bias and lower sample sizes.

When they pooled all the results together without sub-group analysis (i.e. no analysis on smaller, more specific groups of subjects), the medications outperformed exercise by about 4 units of blood pressure on average. Amongst the exercise types, every type performed about the same but the dynamic exercise (standard resistance training) did notably worse by a few units. You could see a positive correlation with drug dosage and blood pressure lowering effects but any correlation with exercise intensity was a lot more ambiguous.

However, we see a different story when we narrow the analysis to only hypertensive populations. As we increase the baseline blood pressure, exercise seems to show better results. In fact, as a whole, exercise performed on par with medications. Some exercise types (endurance and combination training especially) were actually found to be more effective than some medications. Intensities and doses did not show any differences.

Along with the issues previously described, there was no sorting of exercise studies based on their effectiveness. There are organizations which lay out guidelines for proper medication treatment which helps the authors weed out studies that may not be done properly in regards to medication administration but unfortunately, the same cannot be done for exercise studies. This is because there is no governing body which determines which exact programmes are effective or not. Therefore, it is possible that low-quality exercise studies were included in the analysis.

Most studies also start a healthy baseline while we would prefer to see studies done where baseline blood pressures were higher as this is the population we are concerned with. Finally, there needs more reporting of adverse effects in studies where exercise is the intervention. This is done meticulously in most clinical studies. In combination training, there may be a high adverse effect rate because aerobic training can be very fatiguing and negatively affect resistance training performance and safety.

As per the usual conclusions, more studies need to be done but these findings are very promising for exercise in a blood pressure control context. Perhaps in the future, it will be a far more common prescription in health care and maybe even find its way into first-line treatment in non-urgent cases.

TL;DR: In healthy people, medications outperform exercise in lower blood pressure. However, as we increase the baseline blood pressure amongst analyzed populations, exercise seems to perform just as good as medications. Endurance and combination training appear to have the greatest effects.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

Now let’s look at a meta analysis looking at the relationship between muscular strength and mortality done by García-Hermoso et al. (2018). The analysis was done amongst healthy adults and 33 studies were included. Overall, it appeared that a greater muscular strength (looking at handgrip strength and leg extension strength) led to a reduced mortality rate. The reported numbers were a 31% reduction mortality with higher handgrip strength and a 14% reduction with higher leg extension strength. There were no differences amongst age groups but the positive effects of strength were more pronounced in women.

The authors noted a high heterogeneity in studies analyzed. This means that the studies differed widely in methods used. For example, some measured strength with handgrip strength (the most common measure) while some used other tools. This heterogeneity interferes with the pooling of the studies. Despite this, it does seem that the handgrip measure of strength could be of clinical use to assess mortality risk as it is the most popular tool in this literature.

TL;DR: Being stronger may help you live longer! However, more standardization in this area of research would help accrue better evidence.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

It is now time to journey into the world of frequency in training for a bit. It is a trending topic of research and as such, a few new studies have come out of the woods. I will follow a format of covering some recent interventional studies first and then reporting any new reviews/meta-analyses if available. For this article, we will look over the effects of frequency on strength and hypertrophy as those are common outcomes people will focus on.

The theories behind higher frequencies being better for strength include that higher frequencies allow for higher volumes, intensities can be more easily maintained when sessions are spread apart and more sessions give more opportunities to train the neural/motor aspect of strength training.

Ochi et al. (2018) put 20 untrained males through 11 weeks of training followed by 6 weeks of detraining. One group did 1 session a week consisting of 6 sets of 12 reps while the the other group did 3 sessions a week of 2 sets of 12 reps (only exercise performed throughout the study was the leg extension). The intensity was roughly maintained at 67% 1RM with volume matched between groups. Outcomes were one repetition maxima, thigh circumference, quadriceps muscle thickness, muscle stiffness (indicator of muscle damage) and maximum voluntary contraction torque (essentially how much force you can produce about a certain joint).

The higher frequency did have better 1 repetition maximum gains but the authors reported that there were no statistically significant differences and the standard deviations were quite wide. Regardless, this difference can be noted. Rate of perceived exertion was expectedly greater in the lower frequency group by about 30% on average throughout the study. Stiffness was similar between both groups. Thigh circumference had similar results to the 1 repetition maximum outcome in the sense that the higher frequency group had larger circumferences but no significant results were noted by the authors. While non-significance does support the evidence of there being no difference, statistical significance can be wildly variable and issues with this study’s design as well as no reporting of exact p-values, effect sizes and confidence intervals (for this outcome) do not help make a more solid conclusion. Muscle thickness through the measure of ultrasound was similar between groups.

The only statistically significant results reported by the researchers were that at 11 weeks, the maximum voluntary contraction torque was greater in the higher frequency group.

A few problems with this study include the low intensity used in this study. In the real life world, most strength-oriented programmes will use a very high intensity as intensity is an important factor in making strength improvements (Schoenfeld, Grgic, Ogborn & Krieger, 2017). There was no dietary control whatsoever. Finally, there was no control group. However, it was good of the authors to collect data at several time points as it is very common to only see data points at the beginning and end of a study.

TL;DR: Potentially more benefits in higher frequency training (thrice vs once a week), however, there are notable issues with the study design that can affect the conclusions we are able to garner from this study.

A meta-analysis conducted by Grgic et al. (2018) pooled 22 papers together to carefully examine the relationship between weekly training frequency and strength gains. 22 studies were included. Initially, we see a positive correlation between frequency and strength improvement. However, when we control for volume, as expected, we see no such correlation. While this is a common argument seen amongst those who support lower frequencies, I believe these findings are misapplied. Frequency should be seen as a good way to increase volume. Of course, independently, the current evidence points towards a weak correlation between frequency and strength but training with high volumes is much more manageable if the sessions are spread apart. The same findings can be found in a more recent meta-analysis conducted on the subject by Ralston et al. (2018).

Some patterns to note amongst the non-volume matched analyses is that young adults and women responded better to higher frequencies. Upper body, multi-joint exercises were also better with higher frequencies. Women may respond better due to generally having more type I fiber muscle composition which may make them more fatigue-resistant hence being able to handle more sessions per week than men (Haizlip, Harrison & Leinwand, 2015). Improvements in multi-joint exercises may be better because they require more complex motor recruitment patterns which may be poor at baseline but make significant improvements with frequent training. Upper body responds better possibly because the lower body is exposed to constant resistance during activities of daily living moreso than the upper body. Finally, young adults probably have better recovery than older adults which allow them to manage more training sessions per week (Roth et al., 2000).

A big gap in the literature is that there is a paucity of data in trained individuals. This meta-analysis could not even conduct a sub-group analysis amongst trained vs un-trained because there were not enough studies on trained people. More research definitely needs to be done in this population.

TL;DR: When equated for volume, higher frequencies will not do much for strength gains. However, they are a good way to boost training volume. Young adults, women, the upper body and multi-joint exercises may respond better to higher frequency training. More data on trained people is needed.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

To conclude this piece, we will cover a paper completed by Naves et al. (2018). The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of high intensity interval training and sprint interval training on body composition and heart health in 49 healthy, women. All interval training was done on a machine bicycle. High intensity interval training (HIIT) involved doing four 4-minute efforts at 90–95% of maximum heart rate with 3 minutes of active rest in between (active rest = 50–60% of maximum heart rate). The sprint interval training (SIT) involved four 30-second all-out efforts with 4 minutes of light cycling in between. Sessions were done 3 times a week for 8 weeks. Study outcomes include waist circumference, skinfolds (to check body fat) and VO2 peak (a measure of endurance or a measure of how healthy the heart is). Diet was controlled with three 24-hour diet recalls at the beginning and end of the study.

Adherence in both groups was only 75% in both groups which is quite poor. 3 subjects reported adverse effects (dizziness and vomiting). Only the SIT group had statistically significant reductions in body mass but effect sizes were similar in both groups. The reduction in the sum of all skinfolds was greatest in the SIT group with a 22.2% reduction compared to the HIIT group’s reduction of 15.8%.

Reductions in waist circumference were similar between groups. VO2 improvements were also similar. The average timing of the SIT group’s training sessions were 10 minutes shorter on average (23 vs 33 minutes).

It appears that SIT leads to greater fat mass reductions while having shorter training sessions compared to HIIT. Another benefit of SIT is that to perform it, you do not need to know your maximum heart rate. Limitations of the study include not having a more thorough dietary control and the use of skinfolds instead of gold standards like magnetic resonance imaging for measuring body fat.

TL;DR: Sprint interval training led to greater fat loss compared to high intensity interval training in women. Sprint interval training sessions were also shorter on average by 10 minutes. Adherence may be an issue and athletes should be aware of possible adverse effects when undergoing interval training.
