summary: hey, your about page says it's okay to ask for advice on coping, so I wanted your thoughts on this? long story short is that I...
question: hey, your about page says it's okay to ask for advice on coping, so I wanted your thoughts on this? long story short is that I was getting free therapy through my school's clinic. I can't go to another clinic due to transportation and insurance issues. my therapist moved out of the country and last time I went to the clinic, this lady there told me that the clinic isn't really supposed to be for long-term patients anyway, and sort of guilt tripped me about my problems not being 'fixed' yet.
answer:
they told me to go find help somewhere else, except that I can’t. therapy at my school was convenient because I didn’t have to pay for it, and I can’t drive. do you have advice on how you would cope with all this and if you’ve ever been in a similar situation? like what coping mechanisms help you when you don’t have access to a therapist anymore? and just any advice you can share in general related to dealing with mental health issues? thank you.

i do appreciate you sending something in, and if you ever want additional advice you are free to give more info as to what you dealing with since each mental issue is different and can be hard to handle with just a broad general speculation as to what you could be dealing with. always feel free to send more info in either on or off anon, it’s up to you. i don’t want to trigger anxiety if you feel unsafe off anon. 

but with what you have told me, being guilt tripped when you are already having mental issues can only add weight. try to lessen that weight if you have it, and you might not even know you have weight. look back to that moment and remind yourself not to take what they said personally. they are being cold, and i’m sure that they would have been a better help if they had been more considerate to your situation and maybe have talked to a different person, but i’m not going to ask you to go back there since the way you have already been treated. 

i have been in similar situations where people just don’t want to deal with another person’s problems, and that’s how this is coming off to me, which is just sad and cruel. 

i’m not able to get a therapist myself at the moment, but what i can handle is researching some self-help sites and other psychiatric care sites that can give info and advice. that has always been my form of outlet. though speaking to a person can do a lot more since it feels more personal and needed since people are social by nature. but here is some sites that i use, personally, when i feel like i need some more in depth help. 1 / 2 / 3

i understand that the last link is to quora, but there are actual therapists/psychologists on that site that might be of help to you if you have questions there that might do more use than me. 

the best way to cope with this, is to remind yourself of your self-value and not to think back as to what therapist you should find yourself right now because you don’t have the money. but you might be able to find free therapists online that can give you advice. also i’m not saying you shouldn’t find yourself a personal therapist at all, but more that you need to focus on your priorities that can lead you there in the long run, and that means taking care of yourself right now. that way you are stable enough to get money to be able to be a long-term patient for a therapist/counselor and so on. 

coping can have a lot of different meanings to a lot of different people because people cope in different ways. i post a lot of self-care stuff here on this blog, and i will be linking what i think would be beneficial for you at the bottom of this post. 

when i feel at my lowest, when i feel like i have reached a hard spot, i take a breather. it’s good to get a recollection of what’s going on around you and to remind yourself to take a moment and completely separate yourself from the situation. and when you go back to that issue, try finding a different perspective as to how to handle that said situation. don’t put yourself on a time limit and don’t compare yourself to other people. the only time you should compare yourself to people is when you need help self-reflecting and getting to know why you do the things you do, and if you have trauma, don’t blame yourself for not understanding things that other people do because of said trauma. 

coping (the way i’ve always seen it) should be more used as a benefit to helping yourself get better, not more as in a crutch to lean on with all your weight. the more weight you add to that said crutch you might end up breaking it and you won’t have any strength to get back up again. i learned that from experience too. 

coping mechanisms should be more as gentle reminders to yourself to keep going. i don’t know what goes on in your life, so i’m sorry if all this sounds really vague atm. if you need a crutch, something to put your weight on, that depends as to what you are looking for in the long run. if you are the type to put your weight on a crutch that leads to a love-life, you might putting a lot of weight on a loved one. if you are the type to put a lot of weight in finding comfort in life, you might be holding yourself back from doing things that make you uncomfortable. you see where i’m getting at? coping should be a form of finding balance in your life. it can be a lot of work, but it isn’t impossible. 

your crutch should be that of learning balance. balance of what you need and what you don’t need, knowing your wants and separating them from what you need. you might need the balance of finding meaning in your life. (i believe in God, but i’m going more on personal experience there. if you want more info on that you can send another ask in.) so in all reality, the crutch is what keeps you standing while coping is more of those little pieces that become bigger pieces depending on how you use them. sort of like puzzle pieces that either heal you or make you worse. 

here are those links to those posts that might help too (i also added some blog links in case you might need that more than the post itself) :

counsel blog | apologize reminder | gentle reminder | jude blog (she’s an honest sweetie, i talked to her before.) 

if anyone wants to add more links/blog recs, don’t be afraid to. if there is anything more that is on your mind, anon, let me know. i’m not sure as to what issues you are dealing with, but i hope you feel better knowing that you are cared about. if you need me to clarify anything, or give more info on a specific topic, feel free. other than that, i send you good vibes and best wishes on your mental health.
